ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION
STUDENTS SEEKING COUNSELLING SERVICES


    The following Question stood in the name of Mdm Ho Geok Choo -

    1. To ask the Minister for Education in light of the report that there has been an increase in the number of students seeking counselling services in our schools, will his Ministry provide (i) some of the analyses and findings for the students wanting to seek such services and (ii) the number of such students with percentage breakdown and their profile.

    Assoc. Prof. Chin Tet Yung (Sembawang): Question No. 1.

    The Minister for Education (RAdm Teo Chee Hean): Mr Speaker, Sir, from the counselling cases reported by schools, about 6% of students have been referred for counselling, with secondary school students accounting for slightly more than half of these 6%. Of these 6%, 4% were seen by school personnel, including Teacher Counsellors, and 2% were referred to the Ministry of Education's specialists and external professionals. The two main types of problems referred for counselling were discipline-related problems, eg, truancy and late-coming, and emotion problems, eg, coping with grief and loss issues, boy-girl relationship problems. These two types of cases accounted for about three-quarters of the counselling cases reported by schools. Other cases involved bullying and theft, motivation and attitude problems. The students who were referred for counselling came from a cross-section of academic levels, streams, gender and ethnic groups.

    In recent years, there has been a greater awareness among the public on emotional health issues, greater acceptance of counselling as an option, and easier access to counselling services in schools and the community, such as the Family Services Centres. Referrals for

Column: 313

counselling have therefore gone up. The availability of these counselling services is indeed helpful to our students who may need them.

PUBLIC TRANSPORT FARES
(Motion)


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [9th July, 2002],



    "That this House, being aware that Singaporeans are suffering from the effects of a recession, mindful that many Singaporeans, in particular the unemployed, are having difficulties making ends meet and agreeing with the Prime Minister that this is not the best time to increase bus and MRT fares, (a) urges the Public Transport Council to review its decision on the increase in public transport fares; and (b) further urges the Government to take steps to ensure that the prices of public services are not unreasonably increased during these difficult times.". - [Mr Tan Soo Khoon].



    Question again proposed.



    Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong (Tampines): Sir, according to the latest Annual Report of the Public Transport Council, the PTC is driven by the mission to balance the need for public interest to be safeguarded and for public transport operators to remain financially viable. With the fare hikes, coming at a time when Singaporeans are hit by job losses and pay cuts, the feeling on the ground is that the PTC has put the interests of the public transport operators over that of the public. The PTC has lost sight of the larger social mission of public transport.

    Most Singaporeans use public transport today because cars are priced out of their reach, with the Certificate of Entitlement and the taxes on road usage. Public transport is the only affordable means to get to where they need to go, to work, to the market, to get home. It gives them access to employment and, hence, income. As an MP, I sometimes hear jobless residents not wanting to take jobs far away from their homes because it means taking two buses and an MRT ride, which means waking up at 5.30 am to get to work on time. The cost of travelling itself can also be a disincentive, especially if the take-home pay of the job offered is already low.

Column: 314



    The pricing of public transport has a major impact on the lives of disadvantaged people. The household expenditure surveys conducted by the Department of Statistics consistently show that it is the lower-income group, especially those in 1- to 2-room flats, who spend most on public road transport, compared to the other groups. Indeed, the latest survey shows that public road transport takes up 6.8% of the household expenditure of those living in 1- to 2-room flats. This is higher than the average 4% for all households. Any price changes will hit the lower-income most. And we also know that this economic downturn has hit them the hardest. The Government says that it helps them with the Economic Downturn Relief Scheme, the New Singapore Shares and other such financial schemes. But these are often once-off affairs, or for the EDRS, up to three months. But the psychological blow, not to mention the financial impact, of a price increase for something as basic to them as public transport is felt on a regular basis.

    Sir, I do not drive and I do not own a car. I take public transport everyday. I know the service of the public transport has improved over the years. But I also know how it feels to be squeezed in a bus, with no elbow room, and to have to wait for more than half-an-hour for buses that arrive so packed, you have no choice but to wait for another, which comes another half-an-hour later, just as packed. The commuting masses, by and large, do not want frills. They want an affordable but an efficient and convenient public transport.

    I heard the Senior Minister of State Khaw Boon Wan talking about buses being made more sophisticated, so that they can be "mobile offices". Frankly, I dread the day. I find the TV mobile enough of a nuisance. Commuters often use the travelling time on buses to rest, take a nap or just unwind, not as a place to start work. I urge the Government and the PTC not to forget the social mission of public transport as they tinker with fancy and costly ideas that the public does not want.

Column: 315



    Sir, the Transport Minister was reported as saying that the commuters should expect fares to rise because service standards and wage expectations keep going up. I question this. In times of recession, all workers, including bus drivers, have been told to moderate their wage expectations. As for service standards, yes, as I have said, they have increased, but commuters do not want to be made to pay for unnecessary frills. The airconditioned bus interchange is a frill. Why the need to aircondition it when the idea of a quality service is that commuters do not have to wait too long at the interchange for their bus to arrive? True, this interchange is not factored in the recent fare increase, as the bus operators do not have to pay for the capital cost of building the airconditioned interchange. It is paid for by the Government. But they have to pay for the cost of maintaining the interchange. This will surely add to their operating cost. Will this lead to bus operators asking for more fare increases in future, especially as I hear that more airconditioned interchanges are on the cards?

    Sir, the Transport Minister has defended the hikes by saying that transport companies must be allowed to make reasonable profits. It is not clear to us or to the public what are the criteria for deciding if operators are making reasonable or unreasonable profits. In particular, how does the Minister measure viability, given the current economic conditions and the social mission of public transport? Moreover, the operators are operating in a privileged situation, with limited competition. The reasons given by the operators for the fare increases are not compelling. SBS Transit cited increases in statutory costs, such as ERP, as one reason for the fare increase. I know the Government has more than compensated SBS for the ERP charges by lowering the road tax significantly. But given the social mission of public transport, there is also a case for the Government to ease the cost burden by examining if the statutory costs, such as the ERP for buses, can be reviewed. Public transport should be exempted from the ERP, which is meant to ease congestion and to encourage cars to use

Column: 316

alternative routes. Buses have no choice but to ply the routes that they have to. Sir, there is a fear that ERP will only continue to push up the cost of public transport further, especially with night ERP being discussed.

    As for SMRT, it cited energy cost as one factor leading to rising operating costs. Energy cost has risen as a result of electricity tariff hikes. For TIBS, one of the factors cited, among others, is diesel cost. But why should these factors be cited as reasons to raise fares when electricity and diesel costs should be addressed by the Fuel Equalisation Fund (FEF). This Fund was set up in 1992 to address volatile fuel prices and to curb fare increases due to fluctuations of fuel prices. The operators should be allowed to draw from their FEF to cushion the impact of increases in electricity and diesel costs, without a fare increase. As at 31st March 2001, the balances in the FEF are $39.8 million for SBS, $8.7 million for SMRT, and $8.4 million for TIBS. They can draw from this rather than raise the prices.

    I also query the argument that restriction in the number of operators allows them to achieve economies of scale and to balance the profitable routes with the unprofitable ones. Some MPs have repeatedly asked for bus routes within their estates. I myself have represented my residents in asking for Bus Service 292 to link two zones tucked in a far corner of my ward directly to the Changkat Community Centre, but the response has always been, "It is unprofitable. Hence, we can't give you that service."

    I propose that competitive tendering be extended to certain zones. There is potential for lowering costs by introducing competition in awarding contracts to run zonal services within a planned and coordinated network, as has been adopted in other countries such as Scandinavia. On this matter, perhaps more weight should be given to committees, like the Estate Coordinating Committee of a GRC. These committees, which can be found in

Column: 317

Tampines and Pasir Ris GRCs, coordinate estate development and include LTA and SBS representatives as well as grassroots leaders and MPs. Perhaps more authority and powers could be given to this Committee to push forward the agenda for competitive tendering.

    Sir, some Members argued that this House should not undermine the credibility and independence of the Public Transport Council by urging it to review or reverse its decision on fare increases. While I agree that we should not politicise the PTC and its work as far as possible, it is important to assure the public that they have recourse in such matters. This is the case with the Judiciary. Our Judiciary is independent, and it guards its integrity jealously and fiercely. No MP is allowed to ask the Judiciary to reverse its decision. But it has an internal appeal mechanism which makes sure that the system works. If one disagrees with the judgment passed down by the courts, he can appeal to a higher court. But in the case of public transport, there is no higher body outside of Parliament. Moreover, as this case shows, Parliament may not be able to react fast enough to appeals from the public. This sitting is taking place after the fact, after the fare hike has already been implemented.

    I would urge the Minister to establish a public transport ombudsman as a mediator or assessor of last resort for users, and perhaps for public transport operators as well. There should be a body separate from operators and regulators to act as an appeals body. It would help ensure that the system works, that the process is transparent and, at the same time, assure the public that they can get a fair hearing before a fare hike is implemented.

    Finally, with all these fears about price increases, especially in public transport, I want to bring up a cheaper alternative to public transport and cars - and that is cycling. Sir, I declare my interest. I am the patron of the Singapore Amateur Cycling

Column: 318

Association. Cycling is becoming increasingly popular in Singapore, both on and off-road. But our road transport system gives little thought to their use. On-road cyclists find their enjoyment and safety jeopardised by sharing roads with motor vehicles, and off-road cycling may conflict with the interests of pedestrians. Sir, there was a time when I cycled to work from Upper Changi Road to Times House, then in Kim Seng Road, and back. But I stopped after I was knocked down by a taxi. Sir, there are local grassroots and environmental groups, all trying to promote cycling.

    I urge the Minister to consider providing a bicycle lane on roads that can be used by two-wheelers, including motorbikes, for safety and as well as an alternative mode of transport. Such lanes can be found in many developed cities, even those which experience winter. These bicycle lanes are not used in winter, but that does not stop the authorities from providing them. What more for a country with tropical weather all year round?

    Sir, in conclusion, public transport must be guided by its over-riding social mission. The PTC, in reviewing fare prices, should take into account the state of the economy, the unemployment rate, and also the affordability of public transport to the masses, especially the lower-income.

    I support the motion.

    Mr R. Ravindran (Marine Parade): Sir, the motion being moved in this House is a significant one. It is both timely and bold in its call. It was unfortunate that a slew of public service charges have increased over the last few months. It could be that some have decided that it is a politically safe time to raise charges without incurring the public ire.

    Sir, the public has spoken. Looking at the quality and the tone of the letters, comments and feedback, both in the public and private domains, one cannot but conclude that there is indeed a sense of frustration and despair among many

Column: 319

Singaporeans. The increase in the garbage collection charges was the first whip the public tolerated. Then came the carpark fee charges and the public transport fare increases. Collectively, they will make a financial dent in the lives of Singaporeans. Many people are worried how do they cope with these increases when their salaries are frozen and, in some cases, cut.

    Many Singaporeans' feedback was rebutted with the usual statistical and textbook answers. The increase was a small percentage in relation to the overall fare per trip, that is what some said. What it fails to highlight is the percentage increase, and the fact that many Singaporeans take public transport many times a day, and not once or twice, as some people have highlighted. I recall that, during the last four years, some Singaporeans had seen many MPs, in the course of their meet-the-people sessions, with sad stories that they could not afford to go for job interviews, because they did not even have money to pay for their fares.

    Sir, I sympathise with many Singaporeans, particularly our low-wage earners, for whom public transport can come up to 10% of their monthly expenditure if one includes the total income they spend on public transport. Many have not had pay increases for the last few years. Some have their pay reduced, some have just been re-employed, and some are still unemployed. The impact of the public transport fare increases on this group of Singaporeans is tremendous. They are angry but, at the same time, they are helpless.

    I join in the call of the people to demand an explanation as to why public transport fare increase was allowed in these difficult times. Last year, the Public Transport Council took into account the prevailing economic situation and only allowed the alignment of adult feeder fares with the minimum trunk fares. Even then a 10-cent increase, from 50 cents to 60 cents, came up to about 20% increase in the feeder fare increase. I thought it was a substantial amount because many Singaporeans use feeder services in the public

Column: 320

housing estates. It was a substantial jump for many Singaporeans because they use these feeder services.

    For this year, despite no substantial improvement in the economic environment, the PTC has approved an across-the-board increase. I would like to ask the Minister why an increase was allowed when the economy is still in the recovery phase. I am equally puzzled as to how the wage bill for the public transport operators can be increasing, the CPF cut is still in place and wage increases are minimal. When some companies are in the red and many more are without a steady business, was there a real need to pamper our bus companies with a fare increase? For a monopoly who enjoys a steady profit, even in bad economic times, could they have sacrificed more and alleviate the financial burden of the public?

    I would like to ask the Minister whether the present policy for allowing route and transport monopoly is the best model to achieve a good, efficient and reasonably priced public transport system. I am sure the Minister will agree that the public policy favours competition over monopoly. In many countries, public policy relies on the competitive market to establish the price and quality of goods and services. Yet, in Singapore, in the public transport domain, we have monopolies.

    I would urge the Government to seriously consider calling for public tenders to run certain transport routes, which was mentioned earlier by my colleague, Ms Irene Ng. This would certainly not unsettle the present operators, as many of the infrastructure and mass public facilities, like MRT stations, bus stations, and depots, are built by the Government with taxpayers' money. By calling for tender, say, once in five years, I think it will allow these public transport operators to be benchmarked against the market mechanism, and to see whether true efficiency can be delivered by the market.

Column: 321



    In the present set-up, the only available models to compare cost efficiency are the present two operators and the two MRT operators. They enjoy a monopoly in perpetuity. Opening up the market and testing the existing operators against other potential competitors, I am certain the public would benefit. A good example is the case of the garbage collection companies. I understand that the Ministry of the Environment divided Singapore into eight sectors and called for tenders for each of these sectors. The cheapest was selected by competitive tendering and their contract period is limited to five years, after which a fresh tender will be called. I would urge the Minister to consider such an approach as a way to control costs and introduce competition to the public transport sector.

    Let me highlight one more sector to show how competition in the public sector helps control fare increases. Sir, when taxi fares were liberalised, the taxi companies did not increase their fares because they knew that demand was not inelastic. They know that customers have other choices, like bus, MRT, and other taxi companies, to reach their destination. In the case of public transport operators, like bus and MRT, the public has no choice. They are fixed by the present operators - use them or be doomed. In the long run, I do not think that this is the model that we want to have in Singapore.

    Sir, as I was listening to the debate yesterday, I was impressed by the arguments of the Senior Minister of State for Transport, Mr Khaw Boon Wan. He highlighted there are many misunderstandings among the public. However, I felt that there are still a lot of misunderstandings remaining, despite his brave attempt to clear the misunderstandings. Misunderstanding No. 1, which he highlighted, is that fare increases are not due to frills, and that these are paid for by the Government. But what he fails to state is that the operators have to maintain it. As my colleague earlier highlighted, more airconditioned bus terminals are going to come. A PUB

Column: 322

officer advises any consumer who goes there and complains about high PUB bills that airconditioning is the biggest culprit. Here, again, we have to ask ourselves whether the operators are going to bear the cost of these new frills. In his speech yesterday, he did not cover this aspect. The misunderstanding continues. This misunderstanding is legitimate. Perhaps the Government could explain whether it is the Government's agenda, or the public bus operators' or MRT operator's request that such facilities be built.

    Sir, misunderstanding No. 2 is that he explained that fare increases are not to fatten the profits of bus companies. I beg to differ because I cannot see any other reasons. I cannot recollect any of our public transport operators being in deficit, or close to it. They have always enjoyed good profits and they have always come back to PTC for fat profits, not to pull them out of any deficit, or any other serious problem. In any event, as listed companies, they can always go back to the equity or loan market to raise funds that they may need, instead of relying on fare increases as the sole source of raising money for their business. Let us not reward them for their lack of financial creativity.

    Misunderstanding No. 3. It was stated that bus companies have huge losses in other business, and they have attempted to cover it by fare increases. He has explained this misunderstanding. I spoke to many people and they are clear in their mind that there is no such misunderstanding, and that this was never an issue in the debate that has taken place over the last few days.

    Misunderstanding No. 4. He raised the issue whether PTC was uncaring. He said that PTC indeed was caring, and he highlighted some figures. He mentioned that the average wage has gone up by 136% over 15 years. CPI has gone up by 29%, but the transport fares have lagged behind. Unfortunately, no data was provided by how much it has fallen behind the wage group. A better comparison would be to see how much is

Column: 323

transport expenditure in relation to a Singaporean's wage now, as compared to 15 years ago. I do not think there would have been a drop. Indeed, I speculate that the portion of transport expenditure would be higher relative to one's ordinary income, particularly the ordinary wage earner. Naturally, it leaves one wondering whether the Senior Minister of State has difficulty in producing the relevant figures. I would urge the Minister to address this issue.

    In respect of the role of the PTC, I must say that I have great sympathy for the PTC, because they are handling a difficult assignment. How can they be fair to both the public transport operators and to the commuters at the same time? The parameters of their job are defined by an Act of Parliament. My colleagues have raised many issues in relation to the job of the PTC, questions about the conflict of interests, whether the members are qualified to be able to be sitting in the council. And I would like to add one more issue, whether the PTC has, in the course of its deliberations, independent studies put up by think-tanks, or academics, to advise the PTC, or whether they just rely on the reports furnished by the bus companies as the sole source of reference and decision-making. Perhaps some clarification could be given, both by PTC and the Minister to clarify to the public on how they arrived at these figures. Because being a lawyer, I can always say that there are two parts to the argument, and it depends on who presents the argument. If the bus company is the only company that is able to present the argument, I pity the PTC because they need additional support and research from other independent researchers, or academics, to support the PTC in whatever decision that it is going to arrive at.

    Let me now move on to a wider question, and it is whether the type of competition that we are having in Singapore in the public transport market needs to be re-looked. I think it is something that the Minister has to look at the Ministry's level and see whether there is indeed a call which can be justified to re-look at the type of public transport

Column: 324

operators that we have in Singapore, and not rely on some consultant's report which was made some decades ago. That is the format that is being used in Singapore. Considering the present public transport usage and the type of market that we have, perhaps it is time we re-looked at the whole market itself, and see whether we can allow for more competition so that we can achieve greater efficiency.

    Sir, let me now move on to the second part of the Motion that deals with the call to ensure that essential public services remain affordable, and that any price increases during this difficult period should be kept to the absolute minimum. In my view, this is where the real crux of the debate lies. Fare increases are the chosen rhythm of the day. The others, like carpark charges, utilities, have been let off lightly. The wider debate is how do we scrutinise increases in the price of essential services. While we have some mechanism to ensure that some public services are subject to market mechanism and competition, not all are. Some public services are in the hands of the Government, some in autonomous Government bodies, some in statutory boards and some in the public sector. In the public sector, I again applaud the Ministry of the Environment for its practice to call for fresh tenders at the end of the tender period for refuse collection contractors. In some cases, public bodies, like PTC, or CASE, have a role to play. In the case of some essential services being provided by the Government, I would urge the Government to ensure that cost recovery should be its policy rather than profiteering.

    As many of the cost structures and profit numbers are not found in the annual budget numbers, it becomes an impossible task for any researcher to identify these culprits. I would urge the Government to give the mandate to the Auditor-General to look at the Government agencies that provide essential services and determine whether they are operating on a cost recovery or profit-making basis, and to highlight these cases in its annual report. This will provide a good example

Column: 325

of our Government leading by example where its essential services are scrutinised by an independent authority. Perhaps CASE, or a committee made up of the general public, can start a list of such essential services to be scrutinised by the Auditor-General (AG), and this list should be made available to the Government for scrutiny by the AG. This will certainly arrest the trend of some essential service providers, including the Government, charging unreasonable fees and charges under the pretext that they are affordable to the public.

    Sir, whenever a fare increase comes about, or some increase in fee comes about, the usual words are that it is "affordable to the public". This argument is going down less and less with the public, because affordable does not mean it is cheap. It can be cheap and affordable but, in many cases, the yardstick that some of these essential service providers equate is that if it is affordable, the public can tolerate. This should not be the way in which we price essential services. The way we should price it is that we must make it cheap and affordable, not merely affordable.

    Sir, in conclusion, I would like to say that we have a duty to ensure that essential services are provided at reasonable prices and even at subsidised rates, eg, health, education and sports. PUBLIC TRANSPORT FARES



    Debate resumed.

    The Minister for Transport (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong): Sir, thank you for allowing me to join in the debate on the transport fare revision. Many Members have spoken on the original Motion and the amendment as well. They spoke with deep feelings, reflecting the unhappiness amongst many Singaporeans over the recent fare revision. I fully understand and empathise with the sentiments expressed by the Members and by the general public as well. Like the other Members here, I too had to face unhappy constituents and community leaders.

    Sir, it is good to have the chance to thoroughly discuss this issue in the House. For Members to not voice the sentiments of the ground, especially when the unhappiness appears to be so widespread, would undermine our credibility as representatives of the people. The Members have raised many valid points and questions. But there were also many misconceptions. Some MPs, like Mr Ong Ah Heng and Mr Iswaran, have eloquently helped to enlighten the House, and I commend them.

    Sir, I would now like to present some of the pertinent facts and further clarify the various issues. By having the full facts and picture, we can then discuss the public transport policies in a rational and logical manner and arrive at the right conclusion.

    Sir, when I got the Motion, I thought I had better prepare myself and asked PTC for the full details on how they came to the decision. I shall start with the question on the need for the fare revision. Is it justified, and why now, and not six months' time, or even a year later, as some MPs have suggested?

    Let me first inform Members that what I have ascertained is that PTC does closely scrutinise the financial performance and the increase in operating costs of the public transport operators in the preceding year, when considering the fare increases for the current year. They also do take into consideration the state of the economy, how is it impacting on the people, especially the commuters who form the lower level of the social economic group, and they try to make sure that the interests of both are safeguarded.

    By looking at the actual facts, the PTC is then able to make a decision based on the performance of the previous year, and not on projections for the current year. Because, if the PTC were to base the fare increase for this year on what the public transport operators have projected as the increase in cost for this year, their figures will be very hard to answer for or justify. So PTC has taken the right approach.

    Let us scrutinise the cost increase of the previous year in order to consider whether or not to allow an increase this year. Sir, the PTC found that, in 2001, the operating costs of the operators had increased by 6.9% on average. The recent fare revision, as Members know, will increase the revenues of the bus companies by 2.3%. The revision will, therefore, only partially offset the increase in operating costs.

    I must also inform Members that costs had also gone up significantly in year 2000 by 8.5%. But because we were in recession last year, PTC decided not to allow an across-the-board increase to cater for that large increase in costs. It only allowed feeder bus services to increase the feeder fares by 10 cents. And this resulted in a general increase of 1% in the bus companies' revenues.

    Sir, this means that over the past two years, despite the economic downturn, costs for the transport operators had gone up by over 15%. And if we include the 6% CPF restoration, total wages for the employers would have gone up by about 13.7%. Therefore, the PTOs, transport workers and executives have actually exercised wage restraint by holding the increase in wage costs to only 9%, well below the national average.

ROTA

    But profits must be measured relative to the level of the investments needed. The figures are huge. SBS has total assets of over $500 million; TIBS has over $270 million; and SMRT, $1.4 billion, ie, $1,400 million worth of assets. Yesterday, we had a long lecture also from Mr Tan Soo Khoon on the return on equity (ROE) of SBS. ROE is really not a good measure of how effectively a company is using its assets. The better measurement is ROTA, or Return on Total Assets. ROTA is calculated by dividing the earnings before interest payments by their total assets.

    Of the three operators, SBS had the best ROTA, of 8.6 % last year. In comparison, TIBS had 2.9% ROTA, and SMRT, 4.8%. I think the financial analysts will tell us that the rate of return for SBS in 2001 is fairly healthy, but the rate of return for the combined SMRT/TIBS is on the low to very low side. In actual fact, the performance of the two bus companies would have been even lower, if not for two Government measures that we implemented in 1998. Let me go into these two measures.

Road Tax Reduction

    The first is the vehicle tax rationalisation exercise. This was part of the Government's cost-cutting exercise. But it was also to offset the impact of the ERP on

public buses. The road tax for buses was reduced from $5,500 to $1,600 for the single-decked buses, and to $2,000 for the double-decker buses. Arising from this, the two bus companies enjoyed a combined savings of some $13 million a year. SBS alone accounted for about $10 million of the savings.

Extension of Bus Lifespan

    Sir, the second important measure was the extension of the statutory lifespan of buses from 12 to 15 years. This was again done in mid-1998. This means that for three years, from 1998 to mid-2001, the bus companies had a double benefit. First, they could continue using buses which would otherwise have to be disposed of. These buses are fully depreciated, ie, they could use assets which, in effect, were already free. Second, they were able to save the money which they would otherwise have to use to buy the new replacement buses. This means that they saved on the depreciation, plus they were able to earn interest on the money which they did not have to spend.

    To show Members the large amount of money involved, SBS spends about $80 million a year to replace its fleet of buses. In terms of savings on depreciation, and the interest earned on the money which they did not have to spend, it comes up to $10 million or thereabouts a year. And because this is additive, ie, every year another batch is saved, and they have the additional benefit from that batch saved. The savings alone for the third year, ie, in 2001, is about $25 million. So, just for the year 2001, they could save $25 million just on this measure.

    Sir, these two policy changes have helped enhance the profitability of the bus companies, not because of fare increases or productivity improvements. These two measures alone would have saved them a lot of money. In fact, one only has to look at their financial performance in 1997 to get a sense of how well the bus companies were doing without this assistance. In 1997, SBS only earned $21 million and had a ROTA of only 4.4%.
